Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Indomethacin's production and administration as a anti-inflammatory may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams. If released to air, an estimated vapor pressure of 9.9X10-11 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates indomethacin will exist solely in the particulate phase in the atmosphere. Particulate-phase indomethacin will be removed from the atmosphere by wet and dry deposition. Indomethacin exhibited an aquatic photodegradation half-lives 16 and 21 hours and, therefore, may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, indomethacin is expected to have low mobility based upon a Koc of 1400. The pKa of indomethacin is 4.50, indicating that this compound will exist almost entirely in the anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts. Volatilization from moist soil is not expected because the compound exists as an anion and anions do not volatilize. Indomethacin is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Utilizing batch-activated sewage treatment, 31% biodegradation was observed suggesting that biodegradation may be an important environmental fate process in soil. If released into water, indomethacin is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the Koc. Utilizing the DOC river die-away test, biodegradation half-lives of 430 and 410 hours suggesting that biodegradation may be an important environmental fate process in water. The pKa indicates indomethacin will exist almost entirely in the anion form at pH values of 5 to 9 and, therefore, volatilization from water surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process. Bioconcentration is not expected to be an important fate process as anions do not bioconcentrate. Occupational exposure to indomethacin may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where indomethacin is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to indomethacin via ingestion of contaminated drinking water. Use data indiecate that some of the general public are likely to be exposed to indomethacin by direct medical treatment. (SRC)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), indomethacin, which has an estimated vapor pressure of 9.9X10-11 mm Hg at 25 °C(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(2), is expected to exist solely in the particulate phase in the ambient atmosphere. Particulate-phase indomethacin may be removed from the air by wet and dry deposition(SRC). Indomethacin exhibited an aquatic photodegradation half-lives of 16 and 21 hours(3) and, therefore, may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Yamamoto H et al; Water Res 43: 351-62 (2009)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Indomethacin, present at 100 ug/L, exhibited biodegradation half-lives of 430 and 410 hours using the DOC river die-away test. Inoculum were obtained from the Tamiya and Tsumeta rivers, Tokushima City, Japan. 31% Biodegradation was obtained using batch-activated sewage treatment for 6 hours(1).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Yamamoto H et al; Water Res 43: 351-62 (2009)
(2) Fatta-Kassinos D et al; Chemosphere 85(6): 693-709 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: Indomethacin has reported photodegradation half-lives 16 and 21 hours in August 2006 and May 2007, respectively, using an aquatic batch sunlight photolysis test(1,2); therefore, indomethacin may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) O'Neil M, ed; The Merck Index. 15th ed. Cambridge, UK: The Royal Society of Chemistry. p. 922 (2013)

StringWithMarkup.String: A pKa of 4.50(1) indicates indomethacin will exist almost entirely in the anion form at pH values of 5 to 9 and, therefore, bioconcentration is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). Anions do not bioconcentrate(SRC).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Yamamoto H et al; Water Res 43: 351-62 (2009)
(2) Barron L et al; Analyst 134: 663-70 (2009)
(3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(4) O'Neil M, ed; The Merck Index. 15th ed. Cambridge, UK: The Royal Society of Chemistry. p. 922 (2013)
(5) Doucette WJ; pp. 141-188 in Handbook of Property Estimation Methods for Chemicals. Boethling RS, Mackay D, eds. Boca Raton, FL: Lewis Publ (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using an Eliot silt loam soil (2.2% organic carbon, pH 6.6), a Koc of 1300 was reported(1). A log Koc of 2.95 (Kd = 32 L/kg), corresponding to a Koc of 891 , was measured using an agricultural soil (pH 6.3) from Corrstown, Co Dublin, Ireland(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these Koc values suggest that indomethacin is expected to have low mobility in soil. The pKa of indomethacin is 4.50(4), indicating that this compound will exist almost entirely in the anion form in the environment and anions generally do not adsorb more strongly to soils containing organic carbon and clay than their neutral counterparts(5). A Kd value of 214 L/kg was reported using a digester sludge from wastewater treatment plant, Dublin Ireland (pH 6.3)(2). Koc values of 160, 160 and 400 were reported using river sediments from the Akui, Tamiya and Tatara rivers, Japan, respectively(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Indomethacin was detected in 10 of 11 mineral waters at an average concentration of 7 ng/L and 6 of 8 tap water samples at an average concentration of 4 ng/L from within the Turia River Basin, Valencia Spain, sampled in October 2012(1). StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Indomethacin was tested for but not detected in water samples from the Ebro River basin in the northeast of Spain, sampled in June 2004(1). The compound was detected at 0.02, 0.03 and 0.02 ug/L 56, 46 and 4.5 km downstream from treated effluent entry point of a municipal sewage treatment plant on the River Main, Germany, sampled in December 1996(2). Indomethacin was detected in 14 of 22 river water samples from the Turia River, Valencia Spain, at an average concentration of 3 ng/L, sampled in October 2012(3). The compound was tested for but not detected in surface water in Galicia (NW Spain) sampled from November 2007 - September 2008(4). Indomethacin was tested for but not detected at 24 sites in the Elbe River basin, Germany, sampled in April, 1998. It was detected at all 24 sampling sites during August 2000 at concentrations ranging from <5 to 60 ng/L(5). The compound was tested for but not detected in effluent from the Kalby wastewater treatment plant released into the Hoje River, Lund, Sweden(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: The compound was tested for but not detected in Wascana Creek, Saskatchewan, Canada, an effluent-dominated stream sampled from winter 2005 to spring 2007; detection limit = 0.050 ug/L(1). Indomethacin was detected, not quantified in surface water from Hamilton Harbor (Lake Ontario), the Detroit River (Lake Erie) and the Little River (Windsor, Ontario, Canada) sampled in the summer of 2002(2). Indomethacin had a detection frequency of 16% in the 159 samples of surface water, sediments and biota from throughout the Great Lakes Basin with a mean concentration of 0.0047 ug/L(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: 72 samples from three conventional wastewater treatment plants in Spain were studied in 8 campaigns over 2 years starting in 2008. Indomethacin exhibited a 65, 58 and 0% frequency of detection in influent, effluent and sludge samples, respectively; detection limit = 3.0, 2.0 ng/L and 1.0 ng/g, respectively. Overall removal was attributed to chemical and physical transformation, biodegradation and sorption to sludge(1). Indomethacin, influent load of approximately 20 g/day, was 75% removed during a 6-day passage through a municipal treatment plant near Frankfurt/Main, Germany(2). Indomethacin was detected in 21 of 21 influent samples from the Pinedo and Quart-Benager wastewater treatment plants on the Turia River, Valencia Spain, sampled in March 2013 at an average concentration of 0.6 ng/L. It was not detected in the 21 effluent samples(3). The compound was present at 100% frequency (0.1 ug/L median concentration) in influent and 36% detection frequency in effluent (0.06 ug/L median concentration) water from a wastewater treatment plant in A Coruna, Galicia (NW Spain) sampled from November 2007 - September 2008(4). The compound was been detected not quantified in a wastewater treatment work in Ouse, West Sussex, UK(5). Indomethacin was detected, not quantified in surface water downstream from wastewater treatment plants on the Detroit River (Lake Erie) and the Little River (Windsor, Ontario, Canada) sampled in the summer of 2000(6). Based on an average from 7 wastewater treatment plants, an overall removal of 44% has been reported(7).

Reference: (1) Chen Y et al; Chemosphere 93(9): 1765-72 (2013)

The Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) Classification System is used for the classification of drugs. This pharmaceutical coding system divides drugs into different groups according to the organ or system on which they act and/or their therapeutic and chemical characteristics. Each bottom-level ATC code stands for a pharmaceutically used substance, or a combination of substances, in a single indication (or use). This means that one drug can have more than one code: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), for example, has A01AD05 as a drug for local oral treatment, B01AC06 as a platelet inhibitor, and N02BA01 as an analgesic and antipyretic. On the other hand, several different brands share the same code if they have the same active substance and indications.

Pharmacologic Class is a group of active moieties that share scientifically documented properties and is defined on the basis of any combination of three attributes of the active moiety: mechanism of action (MOA), physiologic effect (PE) and chemical structure (CS).  An FDA "Established Pharmacologic Class" (EPC) text phrase is a pharmacologic class associated with an approved indication of an active moiety that the FDA has determined to be scientifically valid and clinically meaningful.
